While this list is long, the bills we passed included funding for hundreds of programs and provisions that will benefit communities across the country.  For more information visit the House Appropriations Committee website for a summary https://appropriations.house.gov/

The package also provides $4 billion for the Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services (CMS), almost $400 million more than the President’s requested budget. This funding is crucial to ensuring that Medicare and Medicaid programs are responsive and effective.
$944 million is also included to improve maternal and child health and reduce maternal mortality and $286 million in funding set aside for the Title X Family Planning program.
This funding will go to crucial mental health resources for children and youth, substance abuse treatment and prevention, as well as increased funding for suicide lifeline and prevention efforts.

The inclusion of $10 million for a suicide prevention program is a step in the right direction for this nation to address mental health issues, which also benefits from the $5.9 billion for the Substance Abuse and Mental Health Services Administration (SAMHSA).

Within the $8 billion significant increases for major public health efforts are included such as $10 million for the establishment of a suicide prevention program, $230 million to address tobacco & e-cigarettes, and $173.4 million for global disease detection efforts.

Specifically, the package includes $2.8 billion for Alzheimer’s research, $3.1 billion for HIV/AIDS research, $195 million for the Cancer Moonshot initiative, and $200 million for research to develop a universal flu vaccine, just to name a few.

We increased funding for the National Institutes of Health by $2.6 billion from last year so that we can pursue innovative treatments and cures to help Americans suffering from a variety of health issues.

In this minibus a substantial amount of funding was granted to many health programs that I care deeply about. The Department of Health and Human Services (HHS) was provided a total of $94.9 billion in funding, $4.4 billion more than in 2019.

And the bill prohibits DOT from playing political games with the funding. Congress is ordering that DOT use these funds to help infrastructure projects that are ready to go and serve an important regional and national need. This includes the Gateway Project.

It includes provisions that DOT must consider transportation infrastructure projects fairly, as quickly as possible, and must provide project applicants with enough advance notice to give everyone time to prepare their project application.

The bill funds grants that finance State of Good Repair projects at $200m, rail infrastructure and safety grants at $325m, and grants to Amtrak's Northeast Corridor at $700m. It also provides nearly $2b for grants that finance new transportation infrastructure.

The $86.2b for the Department of Transportation (DOT), and the provisions included in the bill, are important steps forward for the Gateway Project and replacing the aging tunnels that connect our district to New York.
While we need more than what is included in these bills, the money provided is a good baseline for us to build upon.
As a member of the House Committee on Transportation and Infrastructure, I know how desperately we need funding to fix our deteriorating roads, bridges, tunnels, and rail lines.

This money will go toward the medical services that the VA provides former servicemembers, finances upgrades to the VA's health records systems, and provides $125m to address the veterans' disability claims backlog.

In addition to assisting veterans transition to civilian life, these bills finance our nation's veterans' care programs and military construction projects. It finances the building of new military family housing at $1.3b and provides $216.5b for the Dept of Veterans' Affairs (VA)
...$55m for the Homeless Vets Reintegration Program, $29m for Transition Assistance, and $300k to establish Disabled Veteran Program.
Funding was also allocated to programs that assist our veterans who need help reintegrating after service with $311m for the Vets' Employment and Training Service...
One of the bills provides $1.68b for the agencies and offices responsible for managing our nation's public lands and protecting our natural heritage for future generations to enjoy.

Importantly, this bill also funds the Environmental Protection Agency at $9.06b. This money provides hundreds of millions of dollars for important conservation and climate change mitigation work around the country.

It also provides $502m for the National Wildlife Refuge System and $68m for State and Tribal Wildlife Grants and it funds the National Park Service at $3.38 billion, to preserve and manage the natural wonders that dot our nation.
$495m is set aside for the Land and Water Conservation Fund, which finances projects to protect natural areas and water resources around the country.

These funding bills included money for important environment and conservation programs, too. One of the bills increases funding for NOAA's Climate Research programs to $170m and its Nat'l Ocean Service to $599m. This money finances government climate change mitigation projects.

The package also funds the Department of Energy at $38.5b, with $2.79b going to the office of Energy Efficiency and Renewable Energy, and $425m for the Advanced Research Projects Agency - Energy (ARPA-E). These are the offices whose research yields breakthrough in clean energy.

...with $242m for its Wage and Hour Division, $582m for OSHA, and $106m for the Office of Federal Contract Compliance Programs - the federal offices that make sure workers are treated well and paid fairly.
Ensuring companies meet mandated labor standards is another important priority which is why I voted in favor of providing $12.4 billion for the Department of Labor...

In these bills we made it clear that education must be a priority.  Important programs such as Title I, Special Education, Head Start, Preschool Development Grants, Financial Assistance programs, and more all saw their funding levels increase over previous levels.
Education is another area where our investments have long lasting impacts that can benefit, or hinder, our progress as a society.

In order to ensure that our democratic institutions are operating fairly and efficiently we must have a comprehensive and accurate census. The $7.56 billion for the Census Bureau included in the funding package will help us carry out the 2020 Census.
We also secured $425 million for election security grants to protect the integrity of our elections, a priority that Republicans didn’t fund when they were in control of the House.

Included in those funding bills was $25 million for gun violence research at the CDC and NIH, this is the first time money has been dedicated to this desperately needed research in more than 20 years.

Earlier this week, the House passed 2 funding packages that averted another painful holiday shutdown. While the packages were not perfect, they funded vital programs that will help Americans across the country and include landmark funding for essential initiatives.

Our bipartisan letter was signed by 161 members, over a third of the members of the House of Representatives, and shows our strong support for Taiwan, even as it faces challenges to its democracy and security. Full statement: https://bit.ly/2SeY2hY

Taiwan is already a strong economic partner, it is our 11th largest trading partner worldwide, the 8th largest export market for U.S. agricultural products, and plays a major role in the global supply chain that American companies depend on.

I will continue my work to support legislative efforts to make the United States a global climate leader.
We have the resources and the capacity to be global leaders on this issue and we have a responsibility to future generations to be good stewards of the world they will inherit.
Addressing global climate change will be difficult, but it is a challenge that our country must not hesitate to tackle.

A letter requesting robust funding for the Environmental Protection Agency’s Science and Technology Global Change Research program; and a letter requesting $154 million for the DOE’s Fuel Cell Technologies Office and $50 million for DOE’s Solid Oxide Fuel Cell programs.

Additionally, I signed on to appropriations requests aimed at conservation efforts around the country. I joined a letter requesting $3.576 million for the National Park Service’s Partnership Wild and Scenic Rivers program.

This legislation helps coastal communities prepare for extreme weather by directing the National Science Foundation and the National Institute for Standards and Technology to fund research into infrastructure improvements that account for extreme weather.
Furthermore, I am a cosponsor of H.R. 1317, the Coastal Communities Adaptation Act, introduced by Rep. Harley Rouda (D-CA).
I also signed on to a letter requesting $1.46 billion in funding for the Environmental Protection Agency’s Hazardous Substance Superfund Account.
I led a letter to the House Appropriations Committee requesting an increase in funds for the Department of Energy’s (DOE) Clean Cities Coalition program.

Congress has a responsibility to assist states and communities that want to protect themselves against climate change. That is why I supported efforts to finance climate change priorities in the yearly government appropriations process.
And H.R. 1429 provides $7.5 billion in federal grants for states and local governments that need assistance funding water infrastructure projects.

Both bills invest in our nation’s water infrastructure and its efficiency projects – H.R. 1162 provides $500 million for a federal competitive grant program that provides funding for projects that focus on water recycling technology.

Other bills I have cosponsored are H.R. 1162, the Water Recycling Investment and Improvement Act introduced by Rep. Grace Napolitano (D-CA) and H.R. 1429, the Drinking Water Infrastructure for Job Creation Act introduced by Rep. Maxine Waters (D-CA).

I am also a cosponsor of H.R. 4965, the LEARNS Act, introduced by Rep. Mark Pocan (D-WI), which expands the number of registered apprenticeships available for workers who can be paid living wages during their training, and who are given opportunities for upward job mobility.
This resolution asserts that our country needs to embrace clean energy jobs, modernize our aging energy grid, prioritize energy efficiency in our infrastructure projects.
I am a cosponsor of H.Con.Res.36, Supporting Efforts to Enact a Bold Jobs and Infrastructure Package that Benefits All Americans, Not Just Billionaires, introduced by Rep. Ted Lieu (D-CA).
This bill provides $7.5 billion in funding for investments in transportation infrastructure projects through the Better Utilizing Investments to Leverage Development (BUILD) grant program.

Our country needs to create green infrastructure and shift our energy sector’s workforce towards jobs that build and maintain that infrastructure. That is why I am a cosponsor of legislation like H.R 1428, the Transportation Infrastructure for Job Creation Act.
H.R. 9 passed the House of Representatives on May 2, 2019 by a vote of 231 to 190 and is currently awaiting review in the Senate.
This commonsense bill requires the United States to remain in the Paris Climate Accords and requires government agencies to set and achieve greenhouse gas emissions reduction goals.

We must reengage in the Paris Climate Accords, as the most powerful economy in the world, the United States has a responsibility to be a part of this international effort. That is why I voted in favor of H.R. 9, the Climate Action Now Act.

Mitigating the impacts of climate change must be a worldwide priority. I take this priority seriously and have supported legislative efforts to place our country at the forefront of the fight against climate change.
Throughout the day, I will be sharing some of my efforts in Congress to combat climate change.

Climate change is a real and urgent issue whose impacts are being felt around our country and around the world. Unusually dry summers, rising ocean temperatures, and melting ice caps are all threatening communities.

For more information on my resolution visit: https://www.congress.gov/bill/116th-congress/house-resolution/546 …
My resolution passed the House by a vote of 339 – 71 and will now be adopted by the House of Representatives.

We cannot allow Russia to be involved in the G-7 while it still illegally occupies parts of Eastern Ukraine, commits numerous humans’ rights abuses, and disregards the sovereignty of democratic states.

My resolution, H.Res. 546, Disapproving the Russian Federation's inclusion in future Group of Seven summits until it respects the territorial integrity of its neighbors and adheres to the standards of democratic societies, is of crucial importance to U.S. interests.

Tonight, I managed the #HouseFloor during a series of debates and suspension votes. I oversaw the debate for my resolution, H.Res.546, along with H.R. 3460, intro’d by Rep. Chris Smith (R-NJ), H.Res. 517, H.Res. 585, and S. 178.

Hoy, me uní con @RepEliotEngel, @RepMccaul y @RepRooney para emitir un llamado bipartidista para una extensión inmediata y limpia de #MACCIH. La @OEA_MACCIH es fundamental en la lucha contra la corrupción en Honduras. Lea el comunicado completo aquí:  https://bit.ly/34KF6Ln  https://twitter.com/HouseForeign/status/1201953542958993408 …

Today, I joined @RepEliotEngel, @RepMccaul, and @RepRooney in issuing a bipartisan call for an immediate, clean extension of #MACCIH. The @OEA_MACCIH is instrumental in the fight against corruption in Honduras. Read the full statement here:  https://bit.ly/34KF6Ln  https://twitter.com/HouseForeign/status/1201953542958993408 …
I call on my colleagues to come together and swiftly take up these crucial measures. Congress can act now, with the support of the country, to end the national nightmare of gun violence.

60% of Americans support an assault weapons ban. I am a cosponsor of H.R. 1296, the Assault Weapons Ban of 2019, which would criminalize the sale or possession of any semiautomatic assault weapon or large capacity ammunition feeding device.

I am a cosponsor of H.R. 1236, the Extreme Risk Protection Order Act of 2019, which would incentivize and meaningfully fund efforts to install red flag protections nationwide. This bill respects local jurisdictions and encourages best practices.
80% of Americans support a “red flag” law, which allows state courts to temporarily confiscate firearms from a person deemed a danger to themselves and others by family or law enforcement.
Any handgun owner would have to be at least 21 years old, undergo safety training, pass a background check, and renew their license every five years.
82% of Americans support a licensing system for gun purchases. I am an original cosponsor of H.R. 687, the Handgun Licensing & Registration Act of 2019, which establishes a national licensing system.
H.R. 8 passed the House on February 27, 2019 by a vote of 240-190 and now awaits Majority Leader Mitch McConnell to bring it to the Senate floor for a vote.

93% of Americans support universal background checks. I am a cosponsor of #HR8, the Bipartisan Background Checks Act of 2019, which would require a background check for every sale, possession, or transfer of a firearm in the U.S.

A recent Quinnipiac University poll found overwhelming, bipartisan support nationwide for commonsense gun reform. The good news is legislation exists right now in Washington to transform these popular ideas into law.
